content.rendered:
Lilian Groves knows Durham. She was an undergraduate at the university, then a lecturer and eventually the Vice Principal of Hilde-Bede college. Three weeks after retiring she became a tour-guide for Durham Cathedral and 20 years later, at the age of 91, she is still there.

Thinking about her proudest moment she told me, full of modesty, “I suppose it was being chosen as what was that called? Visit England Superstar. That was probably it.”

In fact, in 2016 she won Durham Tourism Superstar and later in the same year the national equivalent, Visit England Superstar. However, according to Lilian “it was the lead up to it that was amazing as anything else. One of the cannons in the cathedral wrote a song which the choristers sang, and it went viral.” 

Ever modest, she assured me all she had won was “a hideous plaque and a huge framed certificate which is sitting on the floor in my study.”

When I asked her who her favourite visitor was, she replied cautiously: “It’s hard to say. I’ve taken Sting who told me that he wanted to adopt me as his mother. I’ve taken Princess Anne, she was terrific fun, marvellous sense of humour.”

However, her favourite was a local woman from Sunderland. Lilian explained that “she came on a public tour and at the end of the tour she crossed my hands and said, ‘flower I wouldn’t have missed that for a million pounds.’ And I thought that was brilliant, absolutely brilliant.”

excerpt.rendered: The Monocle talks to Durham Cathedral’s most famous tour guide.
